utterances: We will build a wall that works, and I'll get Donald Trump to pay for it.
(LAUGHTER)
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #2: That's awesome.
Lines like that have Cruz supporters fired up in Tennessee.
Aaron Snodderly predicts Cruz will make another big jump when he visits the state again in a few days.
I'm seeing and hearing everywhere that Ted Cruz is our man.
People may not be 100 percent sure they're going to vote for him, but they're 100 percent sure they agree with him.
Cruz still ranks third in the polls in Tennessee behind businessman Donald Trump and physician Ben Carson.
But Cruz has organized a deeper bench of influential supporters - state lawmakers, evangelical leaders, Tea Party activists, gun rights enthusiasts.
People like Snodderly, a former Young Republican state chairman.
Four years ago, he worked for Rick Santorum's campaign which won Tennessee.
Cruz, he says, connects even better.
People support Ted Cruz because they love him.
In 2012, they supported Santorum because they weren't sure if they liked Romney.
Cruz last came to Tennessee in August.
Back then he was polling in the single digits nationally, but his focus on immigration and national security was already resonating with Southern voters.
Even before the attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Cruz was talking about terrorism.
Less than a month before Cruz's visit, a Tennessee-raised Muslim killed five servicemen in Chattanooga.
...Went by the memorial of the four Marines and the sailor who was murdered by an act of radical Islamic terrorism.

Cruz isn't the only Republican candidate who speaks to those concerns, but he's the only one with an organization strong enough to capitalize, says Steve Gill, a conservative activist and Cruz delegate.
So as those other candidates fall off, where do the Carson people go?
A lot of them are evangelical and they're going to go to Cruz.
The Huckabee, the Santorum, a lot of those folks are going to gravitate, I think, to Cruz as you move ahead.
He's going to get a bump there.
It's not just Cruz's supporters who believe he'll surge to the front.
Lieutenant Governor Ron Ramsey is one of the state's most influential conservatives.
He doesn't plan to endorse anyone in the primary, but he's also forecasting a Cruz victory.
My opinion - people walk in there, have their finger half an inch away from the Trump button and say, this was fun, but nah.
That's just my gut feeling, they'll move over to somebody else.
I think the logical person there is Cruz.
Well, you know, South Carolina's a place where President-elect Obama spent a great deal of time prior to the Primary.
And during that time, he - there was a church here, Brookland Baptist Church, that made quite an impression.
As a result, that church choir has been invited to backup John Mellencamp and Beyonce.
So, there is that excitement going on.
Then we have a high school band that's going to be part of the inauguration celebration.
One of our local entertainers, Tray Taylor, is playing at the South Carolina Ball.
So, there's a lot of excitement here.
I don't know who's going to be in South Carolina on Inauguration Day except me.
You know, everybody seems to be heading up 95, headed to Washington, D.C.
Do you have any sense of whether or not there is going to be a quick movement?
You know, right now, you have this situation where so many people are planning on gathering in Washington, but there is this stimulus package, which still requires a huge amount of attention.
Yesterday, the Senate voted to release the second $350 billion of that stimulus package.
How do we think - and I'm going to go ahead and start with you, Cynthia.
How do we think that things will play out over the next few weeks and months?
What are the priorities for using this money in terms of how those emerge?
Because there has been some concern that the first round of funding went almost exclusively to banking institutions, and that they haven't really had to account for where the money went.
What do we think is going to happen with this new $350 billion?
Well, I think that President-elect Obama is a little bit smarter than - to let what happened before happen again under his watch, especially going in.
You know, the new numbers on unemployment and our foreclosure rates came out this week, and they are, quite frankly, alarming.
And so hopefully, he'll be able to do something to give some relief to people in the inner city - you know, people who are really feeling it.
You know, when you compare the need with the fact that so many people have so much hope for his success, it seems like quite a bit, you know, for his shoulders.

But we certainly do hope that as he looks at the stimulus package, that it actually is used to help the people on the ground because too many people feel as if the money before was used to enable people to continue to do much of the same, rip the American public off.
All right, Theola, any sense of how the financial issues are going to play into the first days of the Obama presidency?
I think that Tuesday night, folks will stay out late and Wednesday morning, typical Washington immediately back to work because there's so much to do.
I think that you will see a lot of emerging discussion about small businesses.
Many of them have been hit hard because they're not the large behemoths, to get some of the bailout money.
They're not up there testifying on the Hill.
At the same time, you've got these mom-&-pop, you know, companies, who, you know, they started it 10 years ago with a dream and a hope.
They've got a dozen or so employees and they're starting to have to lay people off and, you know, cut back on health insurance.
And those folks in cities and rural areas are starting to say, what about me?
Where is my bailout?
I think that - I think that everyone may sort of let this moment play out because it is so historic.
But then afterwards, immediately, I think that you are going to see citizens and also folks on the Hill, say, OK, let's get back to work.
We have so much to do to try and turn this around.
Let's talk about a couple of new beginnings.
Former Illinois Attorney General Roland Burris was sworn in as a U.S.
senator this week.
But also you had the hearings about Eric Holder, Mr. Obama's pick for attorney general.
This is a man who said that waterboarding was torture during those confirmation hearings yesterday.
That's a big statement, a huge departure from the current administration.
There were questions over the pardoning of Marc Rich while he was in the Clinton administration.
But overall, do you think that these were a success for the Obama team?
Cynthia?
I do think so.
I think that - I think he will get confirmed.
But I think he has to go through this.
I think that they were - there's so much left over on the Rich pardoning that people still want to talk about because they feel as if the Clinton administration got one over on them.

I also think that as this administration looks to distinguish itself from the previous administration, their position on torture, their position on incarceration of these war criminals - those positions will help to mark the beginning days of Barack Obama's presidency.
And I think he understands that America is concerned about its image worldwide and its position.
And so, I think what we will be - what we will see - is very definitive and very deliberate movement on the part of the Obama administration in those regard.
Theola, you get the final word, and it's going to have to be brief.
Do you think that this administration - the presidency will be marked by an openness to having more reporters of color in key positions covering the administration?
Are news organizations going to take advantage of these cultural changes in America?
I think that they will have to because essentially, the stories that are now emerging because of the Obama administration are now much more nuanced, much more diverse.
You have to write stories about the diversity of the Cabinet.
Now, when you go deeper than that, where do these folks live, eat, sleep?
How do they socialize?
The kind of Washington questions that have always been asked.
But now we have new players in town, not just new because of the government, but then also new in terms of cultural background.
And so, I think that, essentially, the stories will drive the kinds of people who will either be selected or essentially pushed to be in the room to cover them.
All right.
Thank you so much, ladies.

And we were speaking with Theola Labbe-DeBose, a staff writer for the Washington Post; she joined us from the Post studios in Washington, D.C., and Cynthia Pryor-Hardy, the host of the radio talk show, ""On Point with Cynthia Hardy.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
In a few minutes, how two stick figures and a five-letter word landed Seth Rogan's new film in hot water.
First, we've been hearing a lot about undecided voters who may go uncertain into the booth.
For Americans in Iraq, things are a little more complicated.
Army Captain Nate Rawlings is a regular contributor to Day to Day from his post in southern Baghdad with the 1st Brigade Combat Team of the 4th Infantry Division.
Nate, welcome back to Day to Day.
And before we get to the process of voting, I want to ask - the economy, you know, has really dominated the story of the politics here for the last month and even longer, not so much about Iraq.
How did the troops feel about that?
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
Good morning, I'm David Greene.
Our top priorities right now include, of course, maintaining our existing system.
There were some studies showing that the average California driver spends about $700 a year on auto repairs just because of, you know, running over potholes and other kinds of things along the way.
Beyond that, we are investing significant dollars in reducing congestion levels at some of the key chokepoints throughout the state.
You may know that the California ports both in Long Beach and L.A.
and Oakland, we bring in almost 40 percent of the containerized goods that come into the United States from China and other places around the world.

And that's a tremendous burden on our transportation system because when those ships come in and unload the cargo, they're put onto trains and also these 18-wheeler trucks that are also sharing the same freeways and roadways that our commuters are sharing.
Has the downturn in the economy and the rising price of gas made this a more pressing issue?
Absolutely.
You know, we have the challenge that many other jurisdictions have, namely that a large part of the way in which we fund transportation relies upon the gas tax, both state and federal.

So at a time like now when more people are looking for either ways to reduce their need to drive or looking for alternative modes of transportation, what that does if you have fewer people driving or making shorter trips, that's something we encourage and we'd like to see on the one hand.
But on the short term, it creates challenges in our transportation funding.
Dale Bonner is the secretary of California's Business, Transportation and Housing Agency, and we reached him in Los Angeles.
Thank you very much.
Thank you very much.
And with me in the studio is Mr. John Stephens of Springfield, Ohio.
How are you, sir?
I'm doing well.
How are you, David?
I'm very good (laughter).
Do you go by that name often?
No.
I mean, my checks go to John Stephens.
Wait.
Do they really?
Yeah.
My writing credit is John Stephens.
This is probably the moment to say you are better known as John Legend.
(Laughter).
Yes.
We're talking to John Legend.
And that name, Legend - his friends started calling him that because his voice reminded them of some legendary crooners.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""USED TO LOVE U"")
(Singing) Maybe it's me.
Maybe I bore you.
But John Legend really did come from humble Ohio roots.
My dad was a factory worker.
Mother stayed at home with us.
And, you know, we were a working-class family in the Midwest.
And the kind of job that my father does, you know, has become, you know, less and less available in the Midwest.
Manufacturing jobs, you're saying.
So when we talk about, you know, manufacturing jobs in those states, I know very well what that means to have a family that depends on that kind of job for their income.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""I KNOW BETTER"")
(Singing) Legend is just a name.
I know better than to be so proud.
I won't drink in all this fame.
I'll take more love than I'm allowed.
